oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cemeteries; Graves; Women
Cemeteries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scobey family women in the McGavock Confederate Cemetery during the Confederate reunion in Franklin, Tenn.

The McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the nation's largest private Confederate cemetery. Located on 2 acres of the Carnton plantation in Franklin, Tennessee, the cemetery is the burial site for 1481 Confederates killed at the Battle of Franklin. (Carnton served as a field hospital during the 1864 Battle.) Residents John and Carrie McGavock's concern for the remains led to the setting aside of the land and the reinterment of the soldiers in 1866.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park (Ga. and Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Julia Snodgrass Reed standing in front of her old home on Snodgrass Hill, on the Chickamauga Battlefield.

The Battle of Chickamauga was fought in September of 1863 between the armies of Braxton Bragg and William Rosecrans. After days of hard fighting the Confederate Army drove Rosecrans from the field but failed to achieve lasting success. The battle was fought in parts of Tennessee and Georgia and on the farming properties of many citizens. Union Major General George H. Thomas assembled his forces around Snodgrass Hill and furious fighting ensued at the location during the battle.

The Battle of Chickamauga was fought in September of 1863 between the armies of Braxton Bragg and William Rosecrans. After days of hard fighting the Confederate Army drove Rosecrans from the field but failed to achieve lasting success. The battle was fought in parts of Tennessee and Georgia and on the farming properties of many citizens. Part of the battle was fought on "Poe Field," on the property of Larkin H. Poe.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governors Gordon Browning (1889-1976) and Prentice Cooper (1895-1969) standing with two elderly Civil War veterans in their uniforms and another unidentified individual.

Gordon Browning served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives for six terms, beginning in 1922. He was Governor of Tennessee, 1937-1939 and 1949-1953. After losing the nomination to Frank Clement in 1952, he retired from active politics. Prentice Cooper served in the Tennessee House and Senate before becoming Governor, holding that post from 1939-1945. He was U.S. Ambassador to Peru from 1946-1948.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Retirement communities; Older people
Hermitage (Hermitage, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tennessee Confederate Soldiers' Home in Nashville, Tennessee. It is a large brick building with a double front porch and portico. Posing in front are several men who were residents of the home.

In 1890, the Tennessee Confederate Soldiers' Home opened on the grounds of the Hermitage Plantation, former residence of Andrew Jackson. The Soldiers' Home provided care and housing for aging Confederate veterans who resided in Tennessee. The home closed in 1933 and was demolished by 1936. Its bricks were used to build a gift shop at the Hermitage.

The Sons of Confederate Veterans (SCV) sprang from the United Confederate Veterans and is the oldest hereditary organization for male descendants of Confederate soldiers. The SCV was organized in Richmond, Va., in 1896. Membership is open to all male descendants of any veteran who served honorably in the Confederate armed forces.

Kate Litton Hickman was the daughter of Isaac and Lucinda (Tyree) Litton of Franklin, Tennessee. She was married to John P. Hickman. She was a prominent member of the United Daughters of the Confederacy (U.D.C.) and held many offices including: Secretary; Recording Secretary; President General and chapter President. In 1903, she organized a U.D.C. chapter under her name in East Nashville.

Confederate States of America - History; Confederate States of America - Army - Tennessee Infantry Regiment, 1st; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate veteran Victor Vallette appears in a seated position wearing a Confederate uniform. According to family friend and photograph donor Emma I. Sloan, the uniform was obtained for the photo from John P. Hickman during Vallette's 1910 visit from New York City to Nashville and Murfreesboro.

Victor Vallette contended that he signed up for Confederate service in Nashville with the Rock City Guards at the age of fifteen, possibly being the youngest Confederate soldier to serve in the Civil War. He was a private with the 1st Tennessee Infantry (Feild's). Following the war, he went to New York City and became a prominent cigar manufacturer.

The United Confederate Veterans Association was formed in 1889 by several regional Confederate Veterans groups. The UCV was active through the 1940s and held its final meeting in 1951. The Sons of the Confederate Veterans organization was formed by the sons of UCV members and accepts into membership male descendants of Confederate Veterans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Monuments; Monuments & memorials
Andersonville Prison; Andersonville (Ga.); Andersonville National Historic Site (Ga.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Andersonville National Historic Site in Georgia memorializing those Union prisoners who died at the Andersonville Confederate Prison, as well as all other American prisoners of war. The Tennessee Union Soldiers' Monument, dedicated to those lost in Confederate prisons, appears in the foreground, bearing the image of the Great Seal of the United States. Another monument is visible in the background of the image.

The Tennessee Monument is one of the numerous state monuments constructed at the Andersonville National Historic Site in Georgia. The Tennessee Monument was erected in 1915 and is located inside the stockade area of Camp Sumter (Andersonville Prison). The inscription on the back of the stone reads, "This Monument was Erected by the Voluntary Contributions of Their Surviving Comrades and Friends."

Forrest, Nathan Bedford (1821-1877); United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Surviving staff of Lieutenant General Nathan Bedford Forrest's cavalry unit are featured in composite form; oval images of Charles Anderson, J. B. Cowan, George Dashiel, Samuel Donelson, W. M. Forrest, and John W. Morton surround the central photo of Nathan Bedford Forrest. Also listed on the composite are the deceased staff members, and those who served briefly.

Staff officers in the Civil War generally assisted a commander with planning and administrative duties and ensured that command decisions were properly implemented by line officers. In this composite, for example, surgeons, paymasters, quartermasters, and chiefs of engineering, ordnance, and artillery are among those positions mentioned.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Equestrian statue of Nathan Bedford Forrest in Forrest Park, Memphis, Tennessee. Four unidentified individuals also appear in the image, as do the surrounding landscaping and hardscaping.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee Conservation Department
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Henry Niehaus (1855-1935) sculpted the Forrest Monument, which was erected in 1905 in Forrest Park. Niehaus completed at least thirty Civil War monuments during his lifetime. The 1901 United Confederate Veterans Reunion in Memphis provides the best example of the city's devotion to the Lost Cause; this celebration also represented the last great gathering of Civil War veterans. Forrest died in 1877, and he and his wife were buried in Forrest Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate veteran John B. Kennedy is seated outdoors surrounded by his saber, his canteen, his cane, and a small dog. The flag of his regiment, the 3rd Tennessee Infantry, hangs on a pole behind him.

John Booker Kennedy served the Confederacy as a private with Company A of the 3rd Tennessee Infantry Regiment. He was wounded at Chickamauga and at Jonesboro, Georgia. A native of Giles County, Kennedy pursued the mercantile business after the war there and in Lawrence County. Kennedy was one of the six original organizers of the Ku Klux Klan on December 24, 1865, in the law office of Major Thomas M. Jones in Pulaski and proved to be the last survivor of the six.

In 1901 a national Confederate reunion took place on this ground; after that the land sat empty until 1908, when the park opened as "a memorial to the South." It has changed many times: the Jefferson Davis statue was erected in 1964;; a monument to the Battle of Memphis was added in 2008.

Monument honors citizens of Marshall County who died during the Civil War. It stands at the corner of the Courthouse lawn flanked by two restored Civil War cannons. Lewisburg was named for frontier explorer Meriweather Lewis.; The town was the childhood home of Nathan Bedford Forrest, and was the site of the Battle of Farmington during the Civil War.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Columbia (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Confederate Monument in Rose Hill Cemetery. The monument consists of a large stone pedestal with a soldier at parade rest standing on top. It is surrounded by gravestones.; Two more unidentified monuments can be seen behind it. The engraved text states the monument is dedicated to "heroes of 1861-1865."

A face-off at Columbia led to a brief Southern victory in the Franklin-Nashville struggle in late November 1864. Confederate Gen. Hood set up a diversion to cut off the Federal army's line of communications with Nashville.; Federal Gen. Schofield correctly interpreted Hood's moves, but bad weather kept him from crossing to the north bank, leaving Columbia to the Confederates. Thus Schofield slowed Hood's movement but could not stop him.

Commercial buildings can be seen in the background.
The monument at Bolivar was unveiled in 1869. The town was named for South American revolutionary leader Simn Bolvar.

The Battle of Chickamauga was fought in September of 1863 between the armies of Braxton Bragg and William Rosecrans. After days of hard fighting the Confederate Army drove Rosecrans from the field but failed to achieve lasting success.; The battle was fought in parts of Tennessee and Georgia and on the farming properties of many citizens.

The Battle of Chickamauga was fought in September 1863 between the armies of Braxton Bragg and William Rosecrans. After days of hard fighting the Confederate Army drove Rosecrans from the field but failed to achieve lasting success.; The battle was fought in parts of Tennessee and Georgia and on the farming properties of many citizens. Part of the battle was fought on "Poe Field," on the property of Larkin H. Poe. The Georgia monument stands across the road from this site.

The National Military Park was established on December 27, 1894, partly at the request of local farmers, who were tired of their pigs rooting up the remains of fallen soldiers and wanted the federal government to do something about it.; Oversight was transferred from the War Department to the National Park Service on August 10, 1933.

The monument was erected November 30, 1899, by Franklin Chapter 14 of the United Daughters of the Confederacy. Although the Franklin battlefield was small, casualties (particularly Confederate casualties) were high.; Federal casualties amounted to 2,500 men; Confederate casualties were nearly three times that number (7,000 soldiers). Fifteen of 28 Confederate generals were lost in the battle.

The Lookout Mountain War Relic Museum was run By W. E. Hardison. Postcards describing the museum's collections were quite popular.

Snodgrass House was the scene where Gen. George H. Thomas checked the victorious Confederates and saved the forces of Rosecrans. The battle was bloody in the extreme.

Point Park was completed in 1905 to commemorate the "Battle Above the Clouds" as part of the Chickamauga-Chattanooga National Military Park. Land on the mountainside, acquired by the publisher of the Chattanooga Times, Adolph S. Ochs, from the families of Col. Whiteside and Robert Cravens comprised a significant portion of the Chickamauga-Chattanooga National Military Park on Lookout Mountain, although it is not technically part of Point Park.

Built in 1830 by Fountain Branch Carter, the Carter House was caught in the middle of the Battle of Franklin, one of the bloodiest battles of the American Civil War on November 30, 1864.

The United Confederate Veterans organization was founded in 1889 as an association for Confederate veterans of the Civil War. They gathered on a regular basis both nationally and regionally. The 11th Confederate Veteran Reunion was held in Memphis on May 28-30, 1901. In attendance were 2,309 delegates representing about 1,350 camps.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thirteen-page paperback booklet detailing the progress made in the creation of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park. Also included are maps and photographs of various unit memorials.

In 1863 Federal and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, the gateway to the deep South. The Confederates had been victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September, but renewed fighting in Chattanooga in November gave Federal troops final control. Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, the nations first, was created in 1890 to preserve and commemorate these battlefields.

Item is a patented "C. T. Art-Colortone" linen postcard.

Paris native Governor James D. Porter delivered an address at the unveiling of the Henry County Confederate Monument on Saturday, October 13, 1900. The sculpted figure is referred to as the "Private of '61." It replaced a simple shaft that had previously been mounted on the base. The monument stands on the lawn of the courthouse where Confederate military units organized.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Confederate States of America - Army - Washington Artillery Battalion (New Orleans, La.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover image of the "Washington Artillery Souvenir" booklet featuring a tiger surrounded by a laurel wreath with the words "Try Us" printed on a ribbon beneath the image. An American flag appears on the left and a blue flag featuring the slogan "Non Sibi Sed Suis" (not for oneself but for one's people) is on the left. A Confederate banner hangs above the image between the words "Washington Artillery."

The Washington Artillery was formed in 1838 as a militia battery. It received regimental status after serving in the Mexican-American War. During the Civil War it participated in the Battles of Antietam, Gettysburg, Shiloh, Fredericksburg, and Manassas. The regiment saw service in World War II and continues its service in the current U. S. military.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Emblems; Insignia; Symbols
Emblems
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faded red velvet cockade, housed within a folded sheet of paper. Staining marks the imprint of the rosette on both sides of the folded paper. Written at the top card is "Secession Cockade C.S.A., M.E.Y." Notation in the middle is believed to read, "Made by my Mother and worn by me."

M. E. Y. is believed to be Mary Elizabeth Young. She was a North Carolina relative of Gerald Howard Branch, residing in Davidson, North Carolina, and married to Alfred B. Young. Cockades or rosettes generally consisted of knots of ribbons. Used during the Revolution by the Continental Army to designate officers, by the 1860s cockades were used as an emblem of support for Confederate secession. They could be worn by men, women, or children. Federal cockades (rosettes) were also common.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Certificate issued to Ernest N. Haston, a long-serving Tennessee Secretary of State, recognizing financial support and making him a member of the Association committed to restoring the Fort Donelson House. An image at the top of the certificate has the crossed United States and Confederate flags with flanking images of the Fort Donelson House. The date coincides with the government establishment of the Fort Donelson military park in 1928.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fort Donelson House Historical Association
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Built between 1851 and 1853, this hotel served many river travelers and stayed in business until the 1930s. This site of the February 16, 1862, surrender of Brig. Gen. Simon B. Buckner to Maj. Gen. U.S. Grant marked the first major victory for Union forces. Thirteen thousand Confederate prisoners left this location bound for Northern prisons. The Association and the National Park Service completed the restoration of the House in the 1970s.

The local chapter of the Daughters of the Confederacy spearheaded a campaign to raise funds for the monument under the leadership of their president, Agnes Lipscomb Whiteside. Bishop Thomas F. Gaylor and U. S. Senator Thomas B. Turley gave dedicatory speeches.

At its second meeting in Atlanta, Ga., in 1895, the organization changed its name to the United Daughters of the Confederacy, by which name it was incorporated under the laws of the District of Columbia on July 18, 1919.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A crowd of 3,000 people witnessed the unveiling and dedication of Murfreesboro's Confederate Monument on the Court Square. Senator William B. Bate and Governor Benton McMillin attended the ceremony. The monument honors the valor of those Confederates who died at the Battle of Murfreesboro and other engagements in the vicinity. It was funded by the early efforts of the Monument Association and furthered by the work of the Daughters of the Confederacy and the Palmer Bivouac.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Illustration by George Varian of a Confederate soldier leaning against a fence post gazing at a destroyed house. The caption underneath reads "The Confederate's Return - There was only the shell of the house." The image appears on page 537 of Ida M. Tarbell's "Disbanding of the Confederate Army" article. The text above the image discusses Confederate dealings with Mexico. The article appeared in McClure's Magazine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: George Varian
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: McClure's Magazine was founded in 1893 and is often compared to Atlantic Monthly. It is credited with creating "muckraking" journalism. Ida M. Tarbell was an author best known for her book "The History of Standard Oil," which is given some of the credit for the Federal antitrust action against Standard Oil. A leading "muckraker," Tarbell often wrote for McClure's and The Standard. George Varian was an illustrator known for his works featuring American Western themes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Association of Confederate Soldiers was formed, in 1887, by Confederate veterans. The goals of the association included construction of monuments to Confederate soldiers and the Confederate cause; taking care of Confederate graves; recounting war sto; ries that honored Confederates; and, organizing reunions and programs to benefit Confederate veterans, their widows and their orphans. The association held annual reunions for Confederate veterans through 1951.

Hermitage (Hermitage, Tenn.); Veterans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tennessee Confederate Soldiers' Home in Nashville, Tennessee. It is a large brick building with a double porch and a portico. Also pictured are the grounds around the building.

In 1892 the Tennessee Confederate Soldiers' Home opened on the grounds of the Hermitage Plantation, former residence of Andrew Jackson. The Soldiers' Home provided care and housing for aging Confederate veterans who resided in Tennessee. The home closed; on November 22, 1933, and the six veterans still living at the home moved to the Girls Infirmary at the Tennessee Industrial School. The home's last inmate died in 1941.

As a lieutenant of the Confederate Army, he entered Vermont from Canada and occupied the town of St. Albans. He later served as leader of the United Confederate Veterans organization.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Taylor's Cherokee Remedy Of Sweet Gum & Mullein was produced by Dr. James A. Taylor and his father, Walter A. Taylor. They were in business from ca. 1869 to 1884, in Atlanta, Georgia. For a time they were in partnership with John S. Pemberton, 1831-1888, who put out Pemberton's Indian Queen Magic Hair Dye. However, Pemberton is most famous for the invention of the formula for Coca-Cola.

Dr. Robert T. Burt (1873-1955), the son of slaves, graduated from Meharry Medical College with honors in 1897. The well-known surgeon's Home Infirmary was the first and only hospital in Clarksville, Tennessee, until 1916. Named in his honor, it was recognized by the National Medical Hospital Association and the American Medical Association.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front cover of the pamphlet, "A, B, C of the Invisble Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan." It features a central image of a hooded Klan member above the words, "Faultless, Fearless, and Forever Faithful," and the dates, "1866 - Founded" and "1915 - Incorporated." It asks for "an urgent call to real men" from Imperial Wizard Col. W. J. Simmons.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Colonel W. J. Simmons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The pamphlet was produced in 1915 after the Ku Klux Klan was reborn in a surge of pro-Klan excitement stemming from D. W. Griffith's romanticized portrayal of the 1866 Klan in "Birth of a Nation" and the lynching of a Jewish factory owner, Leo Frank, in Atlanta. The influx of new immigrants broadened the scope of the Klan's focus far beyond that of the 1866 Klan. Publisher Thomas E. Watson and W. J. Simmons called the first meeting of the new Klan at Stone Mountain, Georgia, in 1915.

Griffith, D. W. (David Wark), 1875-1948; Dixon, Thomas, 1864-1946; Birth of a Nation (Motion Picture); Gish, Lillian, 1893-1993; Cooper, Miriam, 1891-1976; Walthall, Henry B. (Henry Brazaele), 1878-1936
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Program to D. W. Griffith's film "Birth of a Nation" featuring a cast list; plot summary and technical facts concerning the film; photos of Griffith and the cast; stills from the film's scenes, including battles, celebrations, and the surrender at Appomattox; and various essays on the film and its importance.

D. W. Griffith's "Birth of a Nation" was based on Thomas Dixon's novel "The Clansman," and featured a highly romanticized and specious portrayal of the period of Reconstruction that followed the Civil War. The film pioneered new film-making techniques, such as close ups, deep focus, and jump cuts. The highest grossing film of all time until 1937, its popularity helped cause a resurgence of the KKK in response to the Klan's positive portrayal in the film.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small four-page pamphlet detailing the program for the "Lee Banquet" to be held at the Maxwell House on January 20, 1913. The menu is listed as well as the music for the evening.

Among Southerners, Lee came to be even more revered after his surrender than he had been during the Civil War. Admirers pointed to his character and devotion to duty, not to mention his brilliant tactical successes as he won battle after battle against a stronger foe. His reputation continued to build, and by 1900 his admirers had spread into the North, signaling a national apotheosis.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Canada's application states he enlisted September 1861 under Capt. William Lovelall. He fought in the battle of "Fort Donaldson" (Fort Donelson) and while near the skirmish line on picket duty he was shot and wounded in the right leg. He dressed his own wound with his handkerchief and stayed on post, but the wound has since left him incapable of manual labor. He states he took the oath of allegiance to the United States and was discharged at the end of the war.

He also explains his war-time service and activities since the war ended.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1914 Tennessee State Archivist Gus Dyer developed a questionnaire and contacted all known Tennessee Civil War Veterans in an effort to record their experiences before, during, and after the war. In 1920 the project was continued by then State Libriarian and Archivist John Trotwood Moore and the Tennessee Historical Commission. By conclusion of the program in 1922, 1,650 completed forms had been returned and were made available for research.

William Henry Goodloe (September 20, 1844-February 5, 1940) was one of thirteen children belonging to Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Goodloe. When the Civil War broke out, Goodloe's father offered to send him to a university in England if he would not fight in the war. Goodloe refused and joined up with the Confederates under the command of Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest. He surrived the war and, in 1871, he married Miss Emma Sperry Walsh. They had several children. Goodloe's obituary notes that he "was buried in his Rebel uniform."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs
Goodloe, James Lockhart (1840-19-); Collier, W. A.; Forrest, Nathan Bedford, 1821-1877
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Side view of James L. Goodloe He is dressed in his military uniform and has his hand on the hilt of his sword as if he might draw it out.

J. L. Goodloe was born in Madison County, Mississippi, on September 3, 1840. He enlisted in Company E of the Twenty-eighth Mississippi Cavalry in 1861. Mr. Goodloe was was wounded at Cassville, Georgia, in May 1864 and captured in Allatoona, Georgia,; in June 1864. He was then imprisoned at Rock Island until his parole in February 1865. He would go on to practice law in Memphis, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of the Battle of Franklin, Civil War Centennial, guide book and program. It features a Confederate Soldier in a slouch hat standing on the left holding a musket, and a Federal Soldier in a kepi on the right, also holding a musket. The Carter House is pictured centrally.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Williamson County Civil War Centennial Committee
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Civil War Centennial Commission Records 1961-1965, RG 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The program was commissioned by the Mayor of Franklin and the Williamson County Civil War Centennial Committee to commemorate the 100th Anniversary of the Battle of Franklin. The committee was part of the larger state Civil War Centennial Commission charged with planning, organizing, and documenting the U. S. Civil War Centennial through a campaign of public awareness, education, preservation, and restoration.

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park (Ga. and Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dirt road and a monument of cannons and cannonballs.
The scene is near Missionary Ridge, site of a Nov. 25, 1863, battle that was part of the Chattanooga/Chickamauga Campaign in the American Civil War.
